chapter.htmlHeader: When should I aspirate pre-patellar bursitis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
• Aspiration of bursal fluid provides a sample for analysis to differentiate septic and non-septic pre-patellar bursitis.
    • In addition, it may also relieve pain, reduce bacterial load and increase range of movement.
  • Bursal fluid should be aspirated using a sterile aspiration technique (if the expertise and equipment are available) if:
    • Septic bursitis is suspected.
    • Infection in persistent aseptic bursitis needs to be excluded.
  • If the expertise and equipment for aspiration are not available in primary care refer to secondary care (with urgency depending on clinical judgement).
  • In cases of suspected septic bursitis, aspiration should ideally be carried out before antibiotics are started while awaiting confirmation from the laboratory — for more information, see the section on Management in primary care.
    • Bursal fluid should be sent to the laboratory in a sterile container for Gram staining, culture, and crystal examination.
    • The appearance of the fluid maybe suggestive of the nature of the bursitis, but is not specific.
      • Clear or milky aspirate suggests non-septic bursitis.
      • Purulent aspirate suggests septic bursitis.
  • Following aspiration of bursal fluid the person should be advised to seek urgent medical advice if signs of infection, such as fever or local cellulitis, develop.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on aspiration of bursal fluid are based on a clinical guideline from the American College of Occupational and Environmental Medicine (ACOEM) Knee disorders [ACOEM, 2011] and expert opinion in review articles [Aaron et al, 2011; Hanrahan, 2013; Hong, 2014; Baumbach et al, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].

Aspiration to evaluate bursitis

  • Some experts recommend aspiration in all cases of pre-patellar bursitis to differentiate septic and non-septic bursitis as this is fundamental to successful management [Baumbach et al, 2014].
  • ACOEM recommend aspiration and analysis of bursal fluid to evaluate for septic bursitis. The evidence supporting this recommendation is graded as insufficient and is consensus based [ACOEM, 2011].

Aspiration for symptomatic relief 

  • Expert opinion in some review papers [Baumbach et al, 2014; Hong, 2014] supports aspiration for symptomatic relief but as evidence in support of this is lacking it is not recommended as routine practice in primary care.
  • A rapid response report from the Canadian Agency for Drugs and Technologies and Drugs in Health (CADTH) found no relevant literature related to the effectiveness of aspiration as a treatment for pre-patellar and olecranon bursitis in adults [CADTH, 2012].

 Investigating the aspirate

  • The information that fluid appearance may suggest aetiology of bursitis is based on expert opinion in a review article [Baumbach et al, 2014] and the opinion of a CKS expert reviewer.
  • The recommendation to request Gram stain, culture, and crystal examination is based on expert opinion in review articles [McAfee and Smith, 1988; Baumbach et al, 2014; BMJ Best Practice, 2016].

Advice

  • The advice to the person following aspiration of a bursa is based on opinion from CKS expert reviewers.
  • Complications of aspiration include infection [BMJ Best Practice, 2016].
